Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: I could tell as soon as I walked in that something was off with Mark. He sat on the couch, scrolling his phone, but his jaw was tight, and he barely looked up when I set my bag down. I wanted to sit beside him, ask about his day, and just be there—he always says I’m the one who helps him unwind after work. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: tomorrow’s job site inspection. As a carpenter, I can’t afford to cut corners, not with safety. I needed to check my tools tonight, make sure everything was sharp, clean, and ready. If I didn’t, I’d risk not just my own safety, but my crew’s too. I glanced at Mark, then at the clock. If I started now, I’d be in the garage for at least an hour. But if I waited, I’d be distracted, worried about missing something critical. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the man I love, and toward the responsibility I can’t ignore. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the comfort he needed and the duty I owed to my work.
